sentence1: Once upon a time there was a king who had a three-year old son, and was obliged to go to war against another king.
sentence2: Then, when his ships sailed home again after he had gained a splendid victory, a storm broke out and his whole fleet was near sinking.

sentence1: Then, when his ships sailed home again after he had gained a splendid victory, a storm broke out and his whole fleet was near sinking.
sentence2: But the king vowed he would sacrifice to the sea-queen the first male creature that came to meet him when he reached land and entered his capital.

sentence1: But the king vowed he would sacrifice to the sea-queen the first male creature that came to meet him when he reached land and entered his capital.
sentence2: Thereby the whole fleet reached the harbor in safety.

sentence1: Thereby the whole fleet reached the harbor in safety.
sentence2: But the five-year old prince, who had not seen his father for the past two years, and who was delighted with the thunder of the cannon as the ships came in, secretly slipped away from his attendants, and ran to the landing.

sentence1: But the five-year old prince, who had not seen his father for the past two years, and who was delighted with the thunder of the cannon as the ships came in, secretly slipped away from his attendants, and ran to the landing.
sentence2: When the king came ashore he was the first to cast himself into his arms, weeping with joy.

sentence1: When the king came ashore he was the first to cast himself into his arms, weeping with joy.
sentence2: The king was frightened when he thought of the sea-queen.

sentence1: The king was frightened when he thought of the sea-queen.
sentence2: He thought that, after all, the prince was only a child, and at any rate he could sacrifice the next person to step up to him after the prince.

sentence1: He thought that, after all, the prince was only a child, and at any rate he could sacrifice the next person to step up to him after the prince.
sentence2: The people began to murmur because the king had not kept the promise he had made the sea-queen.

sentence1: The people began to murmur because the king had not kept the promise he had made the sea-queen.
sentence2: But the king and queen never allowed the prince out without a great escort, and he was never permitted to enter a ship, for all his desire to do so.

sentence1: But the king and queen never allowed the prince out without a great escort, and he was never permitted to enter a ship, for all his desire to do so.
sentence2: After a few years they gradually forgot the sea-queen, and when the prince was ten years old, a little brother came to join him.

sentence1: After a few years they gradually forgot the sea-queen, and when the prince was ten years old, a little brother came to join him.
sentence2: Not long after the older of the princes was out walking with his tutor and several other gentlemen.

sentence1: Not long after the older of the princes was out walking with his tutor and several other gentlemen.
sentence2: And when they reached the end of the royal gardens by the sea-shore-it was a summer's day, unusually clear-they were suddenly enveloped by a thick cloud, which disappeared as swiftly as it had come.

sentence1: And when they reached the end of the royal gardens by the sea-shore-it was a summer's day, unusually clear-they were suddenly enveloped by a thick cloud, which disappeared as swiftly as it had come.
sentence2: Nor did he return, to the great sorrow of the king, the queen and the whole country.

sentence1: Nor did he return, to the great sorrow of the king, the queen and the whole country.
sentence2: When he was sixteen, they began to think of finding a wife for him.

sentence1: When he was sixteen, they began to think of finding a wife for him.
sentence2: For the old king and queen wished to see him marry the daughter of some powerful monarch to whom they were allied, before they died.

sentence1: For the old king and queen wished to see him marry the daughter of some powerful monarch to whom they were allied, before they died.
sentence2: Various people had heard cries, and several who had walked by the sea-shore late in the evening had fallen ill. At length no one ventured to go there.

sentence1: Various people had heard cries, and several who had walked by the sea-shore late in the evening had fallen ill. At length no one ventured to go there.
sentence2: At last these complaints came to the king's ear.

sentence1: At last these complaints came to the king's ear.
sentence2: He called together his council, and it was decided to question a wise woman, who had already foretold many mysterious happenings, which had all taken place exactly as she had said they would.

sentence1: He called together his council, and it was decided to question a wise woman, who had already foretold many mysterious happenings, which had all taken place exactly as she had said they would.
sentence2: When the wise woman was brought before the king she said it was the prince who had been taken into the sea who was calling, and that they would have to find him a bride, young, beautiful, and belonging to one of the noblest families of the land, and she must be no less than fifteen and no more than seventeen years old.

sentence1: When the wise woman was brought before the king she said it was the prince who had been taken into the sea who was calling, and that they would have to find him a bride, young, beautiful, and belonging to one of the noblest families of the land, and she must be no less than fifteen and no more than seventeen years old.
sentence2: for no one wished to give their daughter to a sea-king.

sentence1: for no one wished to give their daughter to a sea-king.
sentence2: Yet, when there was no end to the cries and the commotion, the wise woman said, that first it might be well to build a little house by the sea, perhaps then the turmoil might die away.

sentence1: Yet, when there was no end to the cries and the commotion, the wise woman said, that first it might be well to build a little house by the sea, perhaps then the turmoil might die away.
sentence2: At any rate, she said, no phantoms would haunt the place while the building was in progress.

sentence1: At any rate, she said, no phantoms would haunt the place while the building was in progress.
sentence2: Hence no more than four workmen need be employed, and they might first prepare a site, then lay the stone foundation, and finally erect the small house, comprising no more than two pleasant, handsome rooms, one behind the other, and a good floor.

sentence1: Hence no more than four workmen need be employed, and they might first prepare a site, then lay the stone foundation, and finally erect the small house, comprising no more than two pleasant, handsome rooms, one behind the other, and a good floor.
sentence2: The house was carefully erected, and the royal architect himself had to superintend the work, so that everything might be done as well as possible.

sentence1: The house was carefully erected, and the royal architect himself had to superintend the work, so that everything might be done as well as possible.
sentence2: And while the building was going on, there were no mysterious noises, and every one could travel peacefully along the sea-shore.

sentence1: And while the building was going on, there were no mysterious noises, and every one could travel peacefully along the sea-shore.
sentence2: For that reason the four workmen did not hurry with their work;

sentence1: For that reason the four workmen did not hurry with their work;
sentence2: yet not one of them could stay away for a day, because when they did the tumult along the shore would begin again, and one could hear the cries: "First born, first wed!"

sentence1: yet not one of them could stay away for a day, because when they did the tumult along the shore would begin again, and one could hear the cries: "First born, first wed!"
sentence2: When the little house was finally completed, the best carpenters came and worked in it, then painters and other craftsmen, and at last it was furnished, because when the work stopped for no more than a single day the cries were heard again by night.

sentence1: When the little house was finally completed, the best carpenters came and worked in it, then painters and other craftsmen, and at last it was furnished, because when the work stopped for no more than a single day the cries were heard again by night.
sentence2: According to the instructions of the wise woman, it was hung in such wise that from the bed in the bed-room, even though one's face were turned to the wall, one could still see who stepped over the threshold into the drawing-room;

sentence1: According to the instructions of the wise woman, it was hung in such wise that from the bed in the bed-room, even though one's face were turned to the wall, one could still see who stepped over the threshold into the drawing-room;
sentence2: And it was found necessary, though all were unwilling, to follow the wise woman's counsel, and choose three of the loveliest maidens between the ages of fifteen and seventeen, belonging to the first families of the land.

sentence1: And it was found necessary, though all were unwilling, to follow the wise woman's counsel, and choose three of the loveliest maidens between the ages of fifteen and seventeen, belonging to the first families of the land.
sentence2: They were to be taken to the castle, said the wise woman, and to be treated like ladies of the blood royal, and one after another they were to be sent to the little house by the sea-shore;

sentence1: They were to be taken to the castle, said the wise woman, and to be treated like ladies of the blood royal, and one after another they were to be sent to the little house by the sea-shore;
sentence2: for should one of them find favor in the eyes of the sea-prince, then the commotion and turmoil would surely cease.

sentence1: for should one of them find favor in the eyes of the sea-prince, then the commotion and turmoil would surely cease.
sentence2: In the meantime the negotiations for the marriage of the younger prince were continued, and the bride selected for him was soon expected to arrive.

sentence1: In the meantime the negotiations for the marriage of the younger prince were continued, and the bride selected for him was soon expected to arrive.
sentence2: So the girls were also chosen for the sea-prince.

sentence1: So the girls were also chosen for the sea-prince.
sentence2: even the fact that they were to be treated like princesses did not console them;

sentence1: even the fact that they were to be treated like princesses did not console them;
sentence2: yet had they not yielded it would have been all the worse for them and for the whole land.

sentence1: yet had they not yielded it would have been all the worse for them and for the whole land.
sentence2: The first girl destined to sleep in the sea-palace was the oldest, and when she sought out the wise woman, and asked her advice, the latter said she should lie down in the handsome bed;

sentence1: The first girl destined to sleep in the sea-palace was the oldest, and when she sought out the wise woman, and asked her advice, the latter said she should lie down in the handsome bed;
sentence2: but should turn her face to the wall, and under no circumstances turn around curiously, and try and see what was going on.

sentence1: but should turn her face to the wall, and under no circumstances turn around curiously, and try and see what was going on.
sentence2: She had only the right to behold what she saw reflected in the mirror in the drawing-room as she lay with her face to the wall.

sentence1: She had only the right to behold what she saw reflected in the mirror in the drawing-room as she lay with her face to the wall.
sentence2: At ten o'clock that night the royal sea-bride was led with great pomp to the little house.

sentence1: At ten o'clock that night the royal sea-bride was led with great pomp to the little house.
sentence2: Her relatives and the court said farewell to her with many tears, left her before eleven, locked the door on the outside, and took the keys with them to the castle.

sentence1: Her relatives and the court said farewell to her with many tears, left her before eleven, locked the door on the outside, and took the keys with them to the castle.
sentence2: The wise woman was also there, consoled the people, and assured them that if the maiden only forbore to speak, and did not turn around, she would come out in the morning fresh and blooming.

sentence1: The wise woman was also there, consoled the people, and assured them that if the maiden only forbore to speak, and did not turn around, she would come out in the morning fresh and blooming.
sentence2: The poor girl prayed and wept until she grew sleepy;

sentence1: The poor girl prayed and wept until she grew sleepy;
sentence2: She was startled and filled with fear when, her face turned toward the wall, she saw in the great mirror, how a tall, well-built youth entered, from whose garments the water ran in streams to the floor.

sentence1: She was startled and filled with fear when, her face turned toward the wall, she saw in the great mirror, how a tall, well-built youth entered, from whose garments the water ran in streams to the floor.
sentence2: He shook himself as though freezing, and said "Uh hu!"

sentence1: He shook himself as though freezing, and said "Uh hu!"
sentence2: Then he went to the window, and there laid down an unusually large and handsome apple, and hung a bottle in the casement.

sentence1: Then he went to the window, and there laid down an unusually large and handsome apple, and hung a bottle in the casement.
sentence2: Next he stepped to the bed, bent over the sleeping girl and looked at her, strode up and down a few times, shaking the water from his clothes and saying "Uh hu!"

sentence1: Next he stepped to the bed, bent over the sleeping girl and looked at her, strode up and down a few times, shaking the water from his clothes and saying "Uh hu!"
sentence2: Then he went back to the bed, undressed hurriedly, lay down and fell asleep.

sentence1: Then he went back to the bed, undressed hurriedly, lay down and fell asleep.
sentence2: The poor girl, had not been sleeping;

sentence1: The poor girl, had not been sleeping;
sentence2: but had only closed her eyes when the prince bent over her.

sentence1: but had only closed her eyes when the prince bent over her.
sentence2: Now she was glad to think he was fast asleep, and forgot the wise woman's warning not to turn around.

sentence1: Now she was glad to think he was fast asleep, and forgot the wise woman's warning not to turn around.
sentence2: Her curiosity got the better of her, and she wanted to find out if this were a real human being.

sentence1: Her curiosity got the better of her, and she wanted to find out if this were a real human being.
sentence2: She turned around softly, lest she wake him;

sentence1: She turned around softly, lest she wake him;
sentence2: but just as she sat up quietly in bed, in order to take a good look at her neighbor, he swiftly seized her right hand, hewed it off, and flung it under the bed.

sentence1: but just as she sat up quietly in bed, in order to take a good look at her neighbor, he swiftly seized her right hand, hewed it off, and flung it under the bed.
sentence2: As soon as it was day, he rose, dressed without casting even a glance at the bed, took the bottle and the apple from the window, went hastily out and locked the door after him.

sentence2: One can imagine how the poor girl suffered in the meantime, and when her friends and relatives came to fetch her they found her weeping and robbed of her hand.

sentence1: One can imagine how the poor girl suffered in the meantime, and when her friends and relatives came to fetch her they found her weeping and robbed of her hand.
sentence2: She was brought to the castle and the wise woman sent for, and overwhelmed with bitter reproaches.

sentence1: She was brought to the castle and the wise woman sent for, and overwhelmed with bitter reproaches.
sentence2: But she said that if the maiden had not turned around, and had overcome her curiosity, she would not have lost her hand.

sentence1: But she said that if the maiden had not turned around, and had overcome her curiosity, she would not have lost her hand.
sentence2: They were to treat her as though she were really and truly a princess;

sentence1: They were to treat her as though she were really and truly a princess;
sentence2: but that it would be as much as her life were worth to allow her to return to the neighborhood of the little house.

sentence1: but that it would be as much as her life were worth to allow her to return to the neighborhood of the little house.
sentence2: The two girls were all the more discouraged by this mishap, and thought themselves condemned to death, though the wise woman consoled them as well as she knew how.

sentence1: The two girls were all the more discouraged by this mishap, and thought themselves condemned to death, though the wise woman consoled them as well as she knew how.
sentence2: The second promised her faithfully not to turn around;

sentence1: The second promised her faithfully not to turn around;
sentence2: yet it happened with her as it had with the first.

sentence1: yet it happened with her as it had with the first.
sentence2: The prince came in at twelve o'clock dripping, shook himself so that the water flew about, said "Uh hu!"

sentence1: The prince came in at twelve o'clock dripping, shook himself so that the water flew about, said "Uh hu!"
sentence2: Her curiosity gained the upper hand, and when she made sure that he was sleeping soundly, she carefully turned around in order to look at him.

sentence2: She was taken to the castle, where she found herself just as little welcome as her predecessor, and the wise woman insisted that the girl must have turned around, though at first she denied it absolutely.

sentence2: The wise woman accompanied her, and implored her not to turn around;

sentence2: shook himself, laid the apple on the window, hung up the bottle, went into the bed-room, bent over the bed, strode up and down for a few times, said "Uh hu!"

sentence2: though she, always silent, timid, and turned toward the wall, did not dare see more than her mirror showed her of his coming and going.

sentence2: But the two other girls, who had lost their hands, and who now no longer lived in the castle, were jealous of the honor shown the youngest, and threatened to have her done away with if she did not restore their hands.

sentence2: But the sea-queen was enraged and seized the girl, who thought that her last moment had struck, and begged for a merciful death.

sentence1: But the sea-queen was enraged and seized the girl, who thought that her last moment had struck, and begged for a merciful death.
sentence2: The sea-queen looked at her, and asked her who had given her permission to pass beyond the apple-tree.

sentence1: The sea-queen looked at her, and asked her who had given her permission to pass beyond the apple-tree.
sentence2: The maiden confessed her disobedience, and said that she had done so without meaning any harm, whereupon the sea-queen said she would see how she had conducted herself and punish her accordingly.

sentence1: The maiden confessed her disobedience, and said that she had done so without meaning any harm, whereupon the sea-queen said she would see how she had conducted herself and punish her accordingly.
sentence2: Thereupon the sea-queen gave the apple a push, and it rolled back through the portal to the apple-tree.

sentence1: Thereupon the sea-queen gave the apple a push, and it rolled back through the portal to the apple-tree.
sentence2: The sea-queen saw that the apple-tree was uninjured, again pushed the apple and it rolled on to the little fire-place.

sentence1: The sea-queen saw that the apple-tree was uninjured, again pushed the apple and it rolled on to the little fire-place.
sentence2: But when the sea-queen saw the small kettle boiling furiously, while the large one was growing cold, she became very angry, seized the girl's arm savagely and rising to her full height, asked: "What have you dared do here?

sentence1: But when the sea-queen saw the small kettle boiling furiously, while the large one was growing cold, she became very angry, seized the girl's arm savagely and rising to her full height, asked: "What have you dared do here?
sentence2: How dared you take the fire from under my kettle and put it under your own?"

sentence1: How dared you take the fire from under my kettle and put it under your own?"
sentence2: The maiden did not know that she had done anything wrong, and said that she did not know why.

sentence1: The maiden did not know that she had done anything wrong, and said that she did not know why.
sentence2: Then the sea-queen replied: "The large kettle signified the love between the prince and myself;

sentence1: Then the sea-queen replied: "The large kettle signified the love between the prince and myself;
sentence2: Since you have taken the fire from under my kettle and laid it under your own, the prince is now violently in love with you, while his love for me is well-nigh extinguished."

sentence1: Since you have taken the fire from under my kettle and laid it under your own, the prince is now violently in love with you, while his love for me is well-nigh extinguished."
sentence2: "Look," she cried, angrily, "now my kettle has stopped boiling altogether, and yours is boiling over!

sentence1: "Look," she cried, angrily, "now my kettle has stopped boiling altogether, and yours is boiling over!
sentence2: But I will see what other harm you have done and punish you accordingly."

sentence1: But I will see what other harm you have done and punish you accordingly."
sentence2: And the sea-queen again pushed the apple with her foot, and it rolled to the sleeping children, who had been covered with the apron.

sentence1: And the sea-queen again pushed the apple with her foot, and it rolled to the sleeping children, who had been covered with the apron.
sentence2: Then the sea-queen said: "Did you do that?"

sentence1: Then the sea-queen said: "Did you do that?"
sentence2: "Yes," replied the maiden, weeping, "but I meant no harm.

sentence1: "Yes," replied the maiden, weeping, "but I meant no harm.
sentence2: I covered the little ones with my apron so that the sun might not burn down on them so fiercely, and I left with them the apples I could not put in my basket."

sentence1: I covered the little ones with my apron so that the sun might not burn down on them so fiercely, and I left with them the apples I could not put in my basket."
sentence2: The sea-queen said: "This deed and your truthfulness are your salvation.

sentence1: The sea-queen said: "This deed and your truthfulness are your salvation.
sentence2: I see that you have a kind heart.

sentence1: I see that you have a kind heart.
sentence2: but since he now loves you more than he does me, I will resign him to you.

sentence1: but since he now loves you more than he does me, I will resign him to you.
sentence2: Go back to the castle and there say what I tell you: that your wedding with my prince is to be celebrated at the same time as that of his younger brother.

sentence1: Go back to the castle and there say what I tell you: that your wedding with my prince is to be celebrated at the same time as that of his younger brother.
sentence2: From the moment on that the priest blesses the prince and yourself I have no further power over him.

sentence1: From the moment on that the priest blesses the prince and yourself I have no further power over him.
sentence2: But since I have seen to it that he has all the qualities which adorn a ruler, I demand that he be made the heir to his father's kingdom;

sentence1: But since I have seen to it that he has all the qualities which adorn a ruler, I demand that he be made the heir to his father's kingdom;
sentence2: The younger prince may rule over the kingdom which his bride brings him.

sentence1: The younger prince may rule over the kingdom which his bride brings him.
sentence2: All this you must tell them, for only under these conditions will I release the prince.

sentence1: All this you must tell them, for only under these conditions will I release the prince.
sentence2: And when you are arrayed in your bridal finery, come to me here, without anyone's knowledge, so that I may see how they have adorned you.

sentence1: And when you are arrayed in your bridal finery, come to me here, without anyone's knowledge, so that I may see how they have adorned you.
sentence2: Here is the apple which will show you the way without any one being able to tell where you go."

sentence1: Here is the apple which will show you the way without any one being able to tell where you go."
sentence2: It rolled out of the garden and to the castle, where the maiden, with mingled joy and terror, delivered the sea-queen's message to the king, and told him what she demanded for the prince.

sentence1: It rolled out of the garden and to the castle, where the maiden, with mingled joy and terror, delivered the sea-queen's message to the king, and told him what she demanded for the prince.
sentence2: The king gladly promised all that was desired, and great preparations were at once made for the double wedding.

sentence1: The king gladly promised all that was desired, and great preparations were at once made for the double wedding.
sentence2: When the maiden had been dressed in her bridal finery she pretended to have forgotten something, which she had to fetch from a lower floor, went downstairs with her apple, and laid it on the ground.

sentence1: When the maiden had been dressed in her bridal finery she pretended to have forgotten something, which she had to fetch from a lower floor, went downstairs with her apple, and laid it on the ground.
sentence2: It at once rolled to the spot by the sea-shore where she had found the sea-queen and the prince, and where the sea-queen was now awaiting her.

sentence1: It at once rolled to the spot by the sea-shore where she had found the sea-queen and the prince, and where the sea-queen was now awaiting her.
sentence2: "It is well that you have come," said the sea-queen, "for the slightest disobedience would have meant misfortune for you!

sentence1: "It is well that you have come," said the sea-queen, "for the slightest disobedience would have meant misfortune for you!
sentence2: But how do you look?

sentence1: But how do you look?
sentence2: Are you dressed just as the princess is?

sentence1: Are you dressed just as the princess is?
sentence2: The maiden answered timidly, that they were dressed exactly alike.

sentence1: The maiden answered timidly, that they were dressed exactly alike.
sentence2: Then the sea-queen tore her gown from her body, unclasped the jewels from her hair and flinging them on the ground cried: "Is that the way the bride of my prince should look!

sentence1: Then the sea-queen tore her gown from her body, unclasped the jewels from her hair and flinging them on the ground cried: "Is that the way the bride of my prince should look!
sentence2: Since I have given him to you I will give you my bridal outfit as well."

sentence1: Since I have given him to you I will give you my bridal outfit as well."
sentence2: And with that she raised up a sod beneath the great tree, and a shrine adorned with gold and precious stones appeared, from which she drew out her bridal outfit, which fitted the maiden as though made for her.

sentence1: And with that she raised up a sod beneath the great tree, and a shrine adorned with gold and precious stones appeared, from which she drew out her bridal outfit, which fitted the maiden as though made for her.
sentence2: And it was so costly and so covered with gems that the maiden was almost blinded by its radiance.

sentence1: And it was so costly and so covered with gems that the maiden was almost blinded by its radiance.
sentence2: The crown, too, glowed with light, and was set with the most wonderful emeralds, and all was magnificent beyond what any princess had ever worn.

sentence1: The crown, too, glowed with light, and was set with the most wonderful emeralds, and all was magnificent beyond what any princess had ever worn.
sentence2: "Now," said the sea-queen, when she had finished adorning the maiden, "now go back to the castle, and show them how I was dressed when I wedded the prince.

sentence1: "Now," said the sea-queen, when she had finished adorning the maiden, "now go back to the castle, and show them how I was dressed when I wedded the prince.
sentence2: All this I give as a free gift to you and your descendants;

sentence1: All this I give as a free gift to you and your descendants;
sentence2: but you must always conduct yourself so that the prince will be content with you, and you must make his happiness your first thought all your life long."

sentence1: but you must always conduct yourself so that the prince will be content with you, and you must make his happiness your first thought all your life long."
sentence2: This the maiden promised, with honest tears, and the sea-queen bade her go.

sentence1: This the maiden promised, with honest tears, and the sea-queen bade her go.
sentence2: And none any longer dared envy the lovely maiden, for never had a princess brought a richer bridal dower into the country.

sentence1: And none any longer dared envy the lovely maiden, for never had a princess brought a richer bridal dower into the country.
sentence2: Now all went in solemn procession to the church, and the priests stood before the bridal chairs with their books open, and waited for the prince who, according to the sea-queen's word, would not come until the blessing was to be spoken.

sentence1: Now all went in solemn procession to the church, and the priests stood before the bridal chairs with their books open, and waited for the prince who, according to the sea-queen's word, would not come until the blessing was to be spoken.
sentence2: They waited impatiently, and the king finally told one of the greatest nobles to seat himself in the bridal chair in the prince's place, which he did.

sentence1: They waited impatiently, and the king finally told one of the greatest nobles to seat himself in the bridal chair in the prince's place, which he did.
sentence2: But the very moment the priest began to pray, the two wings of the church portal quickly flew open, and a tall, strong, handsome man with flashing eyes, royally clad, came in, stepped up to the bridal chair, thrust his proxy out so hastily that he nearly fell, and cried: "This is my place!

sentence1: But the very moment the priest began to pray, the two wings of the church portal quickly flew open, and a tall, strong, handsome man with flashing eyes, royally clad, came in, stepped up to the bridal chair, thrust his proxy out so hastily that he nearly fell, and cried: "This is my place!
sentence2: Now, priest, speak the blessing!"

sentence1: Now, priest, speak the blessing!"
sentence2: While the blessing was spoken the prince became quiet again, and then greeted his parents and the whole court with joy, and before all embraced his wife, who now for the first time ventured to take a good look at him.

sentence1: While the blessing was spoken the prince became quiet again, and then greeted his parents and the whole court with joy, and before all embraced his wife, who now for the first time ventured to take a good look at him.
sentence2: From then on the prince was like any other human being, and in the end he inherited his father's kingdom, and became a great and world-renowned ruler, beloved by his subjects, and adored by his wife.

sentence1: From then on the prince was like any other human being, and in the end he inherited his father's kingdom, and became a great and world-renowned ruler, beloved by his subjects, and adored by his wife.
sentence2: They lived long and happily, and their descendants are still the rulers of the land over which he reigned.
